Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope to Advance Research and Education at Clarion University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award to Clarion University of Pennsylvania is for the acquisition of a Zeiss EVO LS10 Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). The multiple functions of this SEM, such as high resolution, elemental analysis capability, and environmental mode, satisfies the needs of researchers across the disciplines of physics, biology, and anthropology, enabling them to conduct collaborative, creative, and innovative projects that significantly advance the knowledge of their respective fields.

The acquisition of the SEM is expected to transform how teachers and students are trained and educated in the sciences in rural western Pennsylvania. Additionally, Clarion is partnered with the Barnes Center for Biotechnology Business Development, a product of the Keystone Innovation Zone (KIZ) program funded by the State of Pennsylvania. The high-tech companies in the Barnes Center will have access to the SEM, encouraging further entrepreneurship and providing new research partnerships and training opportunities for faculty and students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Clarion University purchased an environmental Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) to enhance the research infrastructure, teaching, and outreach activities at the university. After an extensive market survey, we identified the best instrument as the VEGA-3 XMU VPSEM from Tescan USA; it was ordered and installed on time. The introduction of this instrument made significant improvements to the research environment and public outreach endeavors at Clarion University. In addition to research projects, professors use the instrument for teaching undergraduates, for undergraduate research, for incorporating high school students into collaborative research projects with undergraduates, and for community service.

The broad impact of the SEM outreach projects developed over the past few years are substantial. In the spring semester of 2015, two professors taught a dedicated SEM class using many of the functions of the instrument. Students in this class learned both theoretical background and hands-on skills in the use of the SEM. Six Clarion students used the instrument for their undergraduate research. Through this process, they became familiar with different techniques and received training in skills such as teamwork and communication. Eight high school teachers and nineteen high school students used the SEM to carry out research projects. These projects are closely related to their interests. For example, one female student has been accepted to a university with a promised spot in a pharmacy school upon graduation. She researched gold nanoparticle synthesis and characterization because she is interested in the potential application of these nanoparticles in the medical field. In addition, the instrument was used to increase the interest of the public toward science and technology, including home schooled students. A picture of high school students making presentation is shown in the attached images.

Research based on the usage of this instrument resulted in significant scientific findings. It has been known that Aluminum-Copper-Iron is an interesting alloy system. In the 1930’s studies identified an unknown phase. In the 1980’s, this phase was identified as icosahedral quasicrystalline phase. A group of Clarion researchers investigated this alloy system recently. A SEM microstructure observation revealed the existence of grains with two different morphologies. They are sphere-like ones with smooth surface and grains with more distinguished facets. The most important finding is the observation of concentric rings on the surface of the sphere-like structures. To our knowledge, such rings have never been observed. Intensive studies are being carried out to understand the mechanism. This finding is expected to bring us new insight regarding the cooling process of liquid alloy and the crystallography. An SEM image of the sphere-like structure with concentric ring is attached in this report.

Clarion-Limestone high school and Clarion University undergraduate students characterized and identified morphological characteristics of charred squash and gourd seeds to assist in the identification of archaeological plant remains, which are generally charred.  High school students from East Forest High School and Venango Catholic High School also worked on archaeobotanical projects.  These included identifying the differences between charred varieties of maize.  The final project compared charred apple and pear seeds.

One geology major identified the method of sediment deposition at the St. Catherines Island site in Georgia. The project focused on determining if the sediments at the site were wind or water deposited based on morphological characteristics of the grains.
